header_summary:
The Bitcoin Foundation has proposed a phased implementation of quantum-resistant cryptography to protect Bitcoin from quantum computing threats, highlighting the urgency with recent advancements in quantum computers by entities like Google. This proposal outlines the transition to SPHINCS+-SHAKE256f for enhanced security and calls for community feedback to refine the approach, ensuring minimal disruption to the network ([source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/4d6ecde7-e959-4e6c-a0aa-867af8577151n@googlegroups.com/T/#u#m6b17340df61fb954ca24db75d171aa8d665e6e67)).

Antoine Riard has developed a natively multi-process full node for Bitcoin in Rust, aiming to improve node functionality and efficiency. This project, still in its demo phase, demonstrates successful block downloading and compatibility across different platforms without a binding generator. Riard’s work emphasizes the potential for enhancing Bitcoin’s infrastructure through cross-language integration and process isolation, underscoring the evolving landscape of Bitcoin node development ([source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/9812cde0-7bbb-41a6-8e3b-8a5d446c1b3cn@googlegroups.com/T/#u#m2ca3b6290d6e305a7e27de46c0a8f971b0069443)).

James T introduced the Quantum Secure Asset Verification & Escrow (QSAVE) proposal, offering a novel approach to protect Bitcoin against quantum computing threats by preserving the principal amount of at-risk coins in protective custody. This initiative seeks to address the vulnerability of millions of Bitcoins through proactive measures and educational outreach, aiming to maintain ownership rights and leverage dormant capital for humanitarian efforts, presenting a balanced response to the emerging quantum threat ([source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/SN6PR12MB2735280A252DD62231D1320AA523A@SN6PR12MB2735.namprd12.prod.outlook.com/T/#u#m4d200793abb1fcfa0608e2e4af53db1145b112d7)).

In discussions on blockchain technology and programming, the development of Simplicity on the Liquid Network is highlighted as a significant step in advancing programming language design for Bitcoin's transaction validation. This work focuses on creating compact programs that efficiently validate witness data, emphasizing static analysis over runtime computation to fit the unique constraints of blockchain technology. The adoption of compositional methods demonstrates how programming constructs can be tailored to meet the efficiency and predictability requirements of blockchain applications ([source](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/delving-simplicity-part-three-fundamental-ways-of-combining-computations/1902)).

recent_posts.title: [Draft BIP] Quantum-Resistant Transition Framework for Bitcoin
recent_posts.summary:
- The proposal aims to transition Bitcoin to quantum-resistant cryptography due to increasing vulnerabilities.
- It outlines a four-phase migration plan to enhance security and ensure backward compatibility.
- SPHINCS+-SHAKE256f is selected for its robust defense against quantum computing threats.

recent_posts.title: Feedbacks on libbitcoinkernel & bitcoin backbone
recent_posts.summary:
- Antoine Riard is developing a multi-process full node Bitcoin project in Rust.
- The project improves Bitcoin nodes' efficiency and has successfully tested on multiple platforms.
- It also addresses cross-language integration, process isolation, and transaction validation challenges.

recent_posts.title: [BIP Proposal] No burn, Quantum Migration Proposal, Quantum Secure Asset Verification & Escrow (QSAVE)
recent_posts.summary:
- The QSAVE proposal aims to safeguard Bitcoins from quantum threats through protective custody.
- It focuses on educating owners and migrating at-risk coins to quantum-safe addresses.
- The initiative supports utilizing returns for public welfare while preserving Bitcoin's principal value.

recent_posts.title: Correcting the error in getnetworkhashrateps
recent_posts.summary:
- The discussion clarifies misunderstandings about hashing estimates' variance.
- The standard deviation is proportional to \(n / \sqrt{b}\) and \(n / \sqrt{k-1}\).
- Decreasing \(b\) and \(k\) increases the error in these estimates.

recent_posts.title: Writing Simplicity Programs with SimplicityHL
recent_posts.summary:
- The approach allows deferring SimplicityHL program commitments to signing time.
- It introduces a flexible *delegation* extension, deviating from traditional models.
- Despite feasibility, the innovative sighash check in SimplicityHL remains unimplemented.

recent_posts.title: Delving Simplicity Part Ⅰ: Three Fundamental Ways of Combining Computations
recent_posts.summary:
- Simplicity's activation on the Liquid Network enhances Bitcoin programming by ensuring compact, efficient validation.
- It introduces basic operations and three composition methods: sequential, parallel, and conditional for versatile programming.
- Aiming for broad computation within blockchain limits, Simplicity excludes recursive composition to maintain efficiency and predictability.

active_posts.title: Taproot is post-quantum secure when restricted to script-path spends
active_posts.summary:
- Tim Ruffing's paper analyzes Bitcoin's Taproot post-quantum security, focusing on script-path spending.
- It suggests a two-phase softfork for enhancing Bitcoin with post-quantum signatures, supported by its findings.
- The study concludes quantum computing currently poses no significant threat to Taproot's security.
